citation.article-title: Leisingera nanhaiensis sp. nov., isolated from marine sediment
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Leisingera nanhaiensis sp. nov.
Leisingera nanhaiensis (nan.hai.en′sis. N.L. fem. adj. nanhaiensis referring to Nanhai, the Chinese name for the South China Sea, from where the type strain was isolated).
Cells are aerobic, Gram-staining-negative, motile rods, 0.62–0.8×1.6-2.96 μm in size.
Colonies on M2 are circular, smooth, glistening, moist-appearing, slightly convex with entire margins, beige in colour and 1–1.5 mm in diameter after 5 days incubation at 25 °C.
Growth occurs at 4–37 °C and at pH 6.0–9.3, with the optimal temperature being 25 °C and optimal pH being pH 7.0–8.5.
NaCl is essential for growth.
Growth occurs in the presence of 0.6–6.0 % (w/v) NaCl, with optimal salinity from 1 to 4 %.
Bchl a is absent.
Cells are positive for oxidase and catalase activities.
Tests for nitrate reduction, hydrolysis of starch, aesculin and Tweens 20, 40 and 80 and liquefaction of gelatin and urease are negative.
H2S and indole are not produced.
Voges–Proskauer reaction is negative.
Arginine dihydrolase, lysine decarboxylase, ornithine decarboxylase, β-galactosidase, β-glucosidase and tryptophan deaminase activities are negative.

In assays with API ZYM strips, alkaline phosphatase, esterase (C4), esterase lipase (C8), leucine arylamidase, valine arylamidase, cystine arylamidase, acid phosphatase and naphthol-AS-BI-phosphohydrolase are positive, but lipase (C14), trypsin, α-chymotrypsin, α-galactosidase, β-glucuronidase, α-glucosidase, N-acetyl-β-glucosaminidase, α-mannosidase and α-fucosidase are negative.
Growth only occurs on complex substrates such as yeast extract, tryptone and peptone from potatoes, as well as betaine and methionine.

No growth is detected on the following single carbon sources: d-glucose, d-fructose, d-galactose, sucrose, trehalose, l-rhamnose, d-sorbitol, cellobiose, acetate, citrate, succinate, d-glucosamine, l-glutamate, serine, leucine and glycerol, except faint growth was observed in the presence of β-hydroxybutyric acid.

The type strain is susceptible to cefoperazone, ceftriaxone, erythromycin, ampicillin, kanamycin, norfloxacin, carbenicillin, polymyxin B, rifampicin, piperacillin, chloramphenicol and cephradine, but is resistant to clindamycin, ciprofloxacin, lincomycin, furazolidone, cephazolin, penicillin G, doxycycline hydrochloride, cephalexin, tetracycline, metronidazole, minocycline, vancomycin, streptomycin, ofloxacin, trimethoprim, oxacillin, gentamicin and neomycin.

The predominant fatty acids are (>1 % of total fatty acids) C18 : 1ω7c, an unknown fatty acid (equivalent chain-length of 11.799), C16 : 0 2-OH, C10 : 0 3-OH, C16 : 0, 11-methyl C18 : 1ω7c and C12 : 0 3-OH.
The major polar lipids are phosphatidylglycerol, phosphatidylethanolamine, an unidentified phospholipid, an unidentified lipid and an aminolipid.
Other phenotypic characteristics are given in Table 1.
The type strain, NH52FT (=LMG 24841T=CCTCC AB 208316T=MCCC 1A04178T), was isolated from a sandy sediment sample from the South China Sea from a depth of 157 m.
The DNA G+C content of the type strain is 60.5 mol% (determined by HPLC).
